message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Adaptive backstepping control for a class of nonlinear systems with output modeling error and external disturbance
Paper Abstract: In this paper, a new robust adaptive control scheme is proposed for a class of nonlinear systems with external disturbance and output modeling error. The output modeling error considered here is allowed to depend on all systems states. Thus, traditional backstepping techniques cannot be used in the controller design due to such an unknown output modeling error existing in coordinate changes. This problem has been solved by the developed robust adaptive control scheme. By establishing the upper bound function of the unknown output modeling error depending on all the system states, the linear inequality relationship between the state vector and the transformation vector is obtained. This is the key to stability analysis. Input saturation is also considered in the controller design. It is shown that the proposed adaptive control scheme can ensure that all signals in the closed-loop system are bounded. Simulation studies verify the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping"},{"title":"Strict-feedback form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strict-feedback_form"},{"title":"Petar V. Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Back mount - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back_mount"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

Here are the search results for **backstepping control**:

## Overview

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a nonlinear control technique that normally takes advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

## How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-integrator strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized, and the stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Key Concepts

Because a strict-feedback system has a feedback-stabilizing control and a corresponding Lyapunov function, it can be cascaded as part of a larger strict-feedback system, and this procedure can be repeated to find the surrounding feedback-stabilizing control.

## Historical Development

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Backstepping is particularly useful for designing nonlinear controllers for complex dynamical systems that can be expressed in a specific recursive structure.

Web search results for query: "nonlinear system control"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Zero dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_dynamics"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Dead-beat control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead-beat_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear Dynamics (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_Dynamics_(journal)"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear system control:

## Definition

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)All real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle.(no content)These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations. Some distinctive properties include:

- Multiple isolated equilibrium points and properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos.
- Solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times (finite escape time).

## Analytical Techniques

The mathematical techniques developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, including limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

## Advantages of Nonlinear Controllers

Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.

## Computational Approaches

If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear system control:

## Definition

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)All real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle.(no content)These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations. Some distinctive properties include:

- Multiple isolated equilibrium points and properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos.
- Solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times (finite escape time).

## Analytical Techniques

The mathematical techniques developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, including limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

## Advantages of Nonlinear Controllers

Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.

## Computational Approaches

If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

Links: [{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"Nichols plot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nichols_plot"},{"title":"Minor loop feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_loop_feedback"},{"title":"Keith Glover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keith_Glover"},{"title":"Power to the edge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_to_the_edge_(management_technique)"},{"title":"Youla–Kucera parametrization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youla–Kucera_parametrization"},{"title":"Innovative Vector Control Consortium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovative_Vector_Control_Consortium"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of robust control:

## Definition and Overview

Robust control refers to theory of feedback regulation that began taking shape in the late 1970's and onwards, where modeling uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged, modeled, and taken into account in control design.(no content)The ability of a feedback control system to maintain stability and performance under uncertainty is referred to as robustness.

## Key Concepts

Tolerance to modeling uncertainty is an essential part of any feedback control scheme, that is, the ability to maintain a satisfactory level of performance when the system dynamics deviate from the nominal value used in the design.(no content)Informally, a controller designed for a particular set of model parameters is said to be robust if it also works well for values of the parameters near the nominal.

## Historical Development

The term robust control was not used until the 1980's when modern methods started being developed to optimize for parametric and non-parametric modeling uncertainty.(no content)The term robust control became almost synonymous with the term H-infinity control, since it was the techniques in the development of the latter that gave the early impetus for the new methods.

## H-Infinity Methods

H-infinity methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance. To use H∞ methods, a control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.

Robust control remains an active and important field in control engineering, with applications across aerospace, automotive, and other domains.

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

## Adaptive Control

Based on the search results, here's an overview of adaptive control:

### Definition
Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain. For instance, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### Key Differences
Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Technical Foundation
The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

### Categories
There are several types of adaptive control approaches:
- Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller.
- Indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters.

### Applications
A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Based on the web search results, "input saturation control" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## General Saturation Control

Saturation arithmetic is a version of arithmetic in which all operations are limited to a fixed range between minimum and maximum values. If the result exceeds the maximum, it is "clamped" to the maximum; if below the minimum, it is clamped to the minimum. This technique is used to prevent overflow issues.

## Digital Signal Processing

Saturation arithmetic enables efficient algorithms for many problems in digital signal processing. For example, adjusting the volume level of a sound signal can result in overflow, and saturation causes significantly less distortion to the sound than wrap-around.

## Nonlinear Control Systems

In control theory, describing functions are used to analyze discontinuous nonlinearities such as an amplifier with saturation, which helps in designing nonlinear control systems where input signals may reach maximum or minimum limits.

## Electronics Context

In transistor amplifiers, for low distortion, the transistor must be biased so the output signal swing does not drive the transistor into a region of extremely nonlinear operation—the transistor must stay in the active mode and avoid cut-off or saturation.

The specific meaning of "input saturation control" depends on your application context—whether you're working with digital signal processing, analog circuits, control systems, or another domain.

## General Saturation Control

Saturation arithmetic is a version of arithmetic in which all operations are limited to a fixed range between minimum and maximum values. If the result exceeds the maximum, it is "clamped" to the maximum; if below the minimum, it is clamped to the minimum. This technique is used to prevent overflow issues.

## Digital Signal Processing

Saturation arithmetic enables efficient algorithms for many problems in digital signal processing. For example, adjusting the volume level of a sound signal can result in overflow, and saturation causes significantly less distortion to the sound than wrap-around.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability theory"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Foster's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foster's_theorem"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"}]

## Lyapunov Stability Theory

Lyapunov stability theory is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended his thesis on stability of motion in 1892. He pioneered a global approach to analyzing the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems, in contrast to the widely used local method of linearizing around equilibrium points.

### Core Concepts

In dynamical systems, an orbit is called Lyapunov stable if the forward orbit of any point stays in a small neighborhood.(no content)Asymptotic stability means that solutions starting close enough to an equilibrium not only remain close but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

### Lyapunov Functions

Lyapunov functions are scalar functions used to prove the stability of an equilibrium in ordinary differential equations and are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.(no content)For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.

### Applications

Interest in Lyapunov's "Second Method" skyrocketed during the Cold War when it was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems containing strong nonlinearities.(no content)Input-to-state stability (ISS) unified Lyapunov and input-output stability theories and revolutionized views on stabilization of nonlinear systems and design of robust nonlinear observers.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Adaptive backstepping control for a class of nonlinear systems with output modeling error and external disturbance". Here's a summary:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes a new robust adaptive control scheme)

**Key Triples Extracted (5 total):**

1. **Backstepping** (method) - USES: The paper extends traditional backstepping techniques to handle output modeling error, which prevents direct application of standard backstepping.

2. **Adaptive control** (method) - USES: Adaptive control is the foundational technique that the proposed robust adaptive control scheme builds upon.

3. **Nonlinear control** (method) - USES: The paper addresses control of nonlinear systems, which requires specialized nonlinear control techniques.

4. **Robust control** (method) - PROPOSES: The paper proposes a new robust adaptive control scheme that handles unknown disturbances and modeling errors.

5. **Lyapunov stability** (concept) - USES: Lyapunov stability analysis is the key theoretical tool used to establish stability of the proposed control scheme.

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED - All checks passed successfully with 4 methods and 1 concept entity type.

The triples have been saved to `triples_output.json` with proper Wikipedia references and are ready for use in the knowledge graph.

- [Nonlinear control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control)
- [Robust control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control)
- [Lyapunov stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability)
